data.title: Summit
data.statement:
Given a mountain range, your task is to find how long it takes to reach to the tallest peak, starting from column 1. You need to output the time it takes to reach the tallest peak starting from mountain 1. The distance is only the horizontal distance, no matter the vertical distance. {{0}}s are air and {{#}}s are mountains.

<<Example>>:
`000#000
0#0#0#0
#######`
The time it takes to reach the [[i]]th mountain starting from mountain 1 is simply the distance between the [[i]]th mountain and the 1st mountain. It's obvious to see that the tallest mountain is the 4th mountain, and the time it takes to reach it is 4-1=3 (ie. the distance between the fourth mountain and the first mountain)

<<Note:>>
The first column always contains a mountain and is denoted as Mountain 1. A mountain always starts on the ground (the bottom row) and continues up to its peak.
You can't move across air
data.constraints:
1 <= [[n]] <= 10
1 <= [[w]] <= 25
There is always only 1 tallest peak
data.stubGenerator:
read n:int
loop n
read mountain:string(25)
write Answer here!
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> an integer [[n]].
<<Next [[n]] lines:>> a line in the photo of air and mountains.
Each of the [[n]] lines consist of [[w]] characters: {{0}} as air and {{#}} as a mountain.
data.outputDescription: The time it takes to reach the tallest peak starting from mountain 1.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Given a mountain range, your task is to find how long it takes to reach to the tallest peak, starting from column 1. You need to output the time it takes to reach the tallest peak starting from mountain 1. The distance is only the horizontal distance, no matter the vertical distance. 0s are air and #s are mountains.

Example:
000#000
0#0#0#0
#######

The time it takes to reach the ith mountain starting from mountain 1 is simply the distance between the ith mountain and the 1st mountain. It's obvious to see that the tallest mountain is the 4th mountain, and the time it takes to reach it is 4-1=3 (ie. the distance between the fourth mountain and the first mountain)

Note:
The first column always contains a mountain and is denoted as Mountain 1. A mountain always starts on the ground (the bottom row) and continues up to its peak.
You can't move across air
Input
Line 1: an integer n.
Next n lines: a line in the photo of air and mountains.
Each of the n lines consist of w characters: 0 as air and # as a mountain.
Output
The time it takes to reach the tallest peak starting from mountain 1.
Constraints
1 <= n <= 10
1 <= w <= 25
There is always only 1 tallest peak
Example
Input
3
000#000
0#0#0#0
#######
Output
3
